Look--I love sports. I love college athletics. I think athletics can, and often does, enrich the student experience and the life of the institution. I work at a D-1 school. But football-driven realignment is absolutely a destructive force, and it's going to eat the rest of athletics alive.
🎶 one of these things is not like the others 🎵

Now consider that few athletic departments actually generate enough revenue to share with academics. Rutgers, for example, has seen losses over $20M from athletics. So when these newly-arrived power conference unis have to spend more $$ for travel, etc, expect to see more LSU-Library-type situations

Of course, unis will still pay those bills because athletics rule all. Example: LSU athletics actually turns a profit, but the athletic dept resents sharing w. academics--and the library at LSU is a decrepit, mold-infested disaster of a building.  www.wwltv.com/article/news...

It is already difficult to be a D-I student athlete. The conference realignment we've seen this year is going to make it exponentially worse: more missed classes and brutal travel schedules. And higher costs for universities at a time where few, if any, can afford it.

For football, this is merely absurd. For other sports, it's a disaster. 4 conference away games on weekends is one thing. Softball teams flying from SFO to Greenville/Spartanburg for a midweek series is another thing entirely. Football is devouring other college sports. www.espn.com/college-spor...
